intro: Grammitis pradoana, commonly known as the Prado's spikemoss, is a member of the family Huperjiaceae and is native to tropical regions of South America. It is a small, terrestrial fern that typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and rocky crevices. The plant has a distinctive appearance with its slender, branching stems and small, lance-shaped leaves. It produces spores in specialized structures called sporangia, which are clustered in dense, spiky formations along the stems. Grammitis pradoana plays a role in maintaining soil stability and providing habitat for microorganisms in its native ecosystem.
